                        of Mulgrave</tei-persName> is to preside. Very many young persons also, we understand, have selected this day, in preference to all others, for being joined together in holy matrimony.”</tei-q></tei-p>
               <tei-p data-origname="p">- We read the following in <tei-title type="periodical" data-origname="title" data-origatts="type">the Sun</tei-title>:</tei-p>
               <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-q data-origname="q">“We learn that the people in several parts of the kingdom have prepared to celebrate this day as a public festival, and the intelligence has given us great satisfaction. But whether the celebration of it begin this year or the next, certain are we that the descendants of the British people will regard it as the proudest memento of England’s munificence.”</tei-q></tei-p>
               <tei-pb n="33" facs="v1n2p33" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
            </tei-div>

            <tei-div data-origname="div">
               <tei-head n="(supplement)" data-origname="head" data-origatts="n">(SUPPLEMENT)</tei-head>

COLONIES FRANÇAISES.</tei-head>
            </tei-div>

            <tei-div type="article" data-origname="div" data-origatts="type">
               <tei-head n="Martinique." data-origname="head" data-origatts="n"><tei-placeName ref="#MQ" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">MARTINIQUE.</tei-placeName></tei-head>
               <tei-p data-origname="p">We receive this letter from the town of <tei-placeName ref="#TRI" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">La Trinité</tei-placeName> :</tei-p>
               <tei-q data-origname="q"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Bardel</tei-persName>,  captain of a militia company in <tei-placeName ref="#MQ" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref"> Martinique</tei-placeName>,  encounters <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr.
                        Igout</tei-persName>, colonist, formerly a merchant at <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">
                       La Trinité</tei-placeName>, who looks for trouble with him, insults him and threatens him with his stick. The reason is that <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Bardel</tei-persName>
                     was probably in a bad mood. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Igout</tei-persName>, who because of his age and infirmities can not punish this insolent provocation on his own, flees the promised blows.
                       But <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Frotté</tei-persName>,  man of color and natural son of this merchant, present at the scene, cannot contain his indignation, and takes his father’s side. 
                     Should he not be blamed had he remained a cowardly, passive spectator to the outrage addressed to the white hair of the author of his days? <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Bardel</tei-persName> 
                     challenges <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Frotté</tei-persName> to a duel. The latter asks
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Eudoxie Sugnin</tei-persName>, his friend, to agree with his opponent’s witnesses on the mode and conditions of their combat. Thanks to the firm but conciliatory intervention of 
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Sugnin</tei-persName>, the affair is amicably settled, with no cost to <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Frotté</tei-persName>'s honor. Yet, by not selling short his friend’s dignity, 
                  <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Sugnin</tei-persName>
                     incurred <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Bardel</tei-persName>'s, grudge, who only waited for an opportunity to satisfy it: it presented itself quickly.
A review of the national guard takes place, which Mr. Sugnin does not attend.
<tei-persName data-origname="persName">Captain Bardel</tei-persName> issues an order for Mr. Sugnin to spend 48 hours in the police room; ; the order is approved by Commander Commissar <tei-persName ref="#SebPC" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Caffié</tei-persName>, who also holds personal animosity against
                     Mr. Sugnin.  (We apologize that limited space does not allow us to copy in full this curious piece). Note that at least a third of the company led by 
                     Mr. Bardel was missing the review, and that only Mr. Sugnin was punished. The story above explains this selective severity.
                     Let us add that<tei-pb n="34" facs="v1n2p34" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Sugnin</tei-persName> is an ardent and devoted patriot. To the arbitrary punishment inflicted on him by <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr.
                        Bardel</tei-persName>'s whim, was added a no less arbitrary and much more odious surplus of rigor: Mr. Sugnin having complained about the arbitrary detention, 
                  a complaint to the superior authorities of the colony was filed against him; and on the governor’s orders, he was taken by the gendarmerie of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">La Trinité</tei-placeName> 
                  the so-called <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Redoute-Bouillé</tei-emph> citadel at <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Fort-Royal</tei-placeName>, where he was kept in a dungeon for six days. During his detention, 
                  Mr. Sugnin, cruelly tormented by hunger, was denied food, because it had been ordered that he could not even communicate with his parents. Only thanks to the pity of the soldiers 
                  of the garrison guarding the citadel did he receive any victuals.
               </tei-q>
               <tei-p data-origname="p">Is this not arbitrariness given free reins? Missing a review becomes an offense punishable with 48 hour detention, and then, through a superior order, six days in a dungeon! A captain takes it upon himself to declare this first sentence, and to add starvation to it! A commander approves, a governor tolerates it, what disgusting defilement! In truth, reading or hearing such things makes you think you’re dreaming, and your jaw might drop, did you not recall that such facts and many others whose account we spare our readers have occurred in one of our colonies, traditional land of arbitrariness and oppression. </tei-p>
               <tei-p data-origname="p">Are not these facts evidence of the necessity to quickly reorganize the colonial militias? In our next issue, we will examine the issues of rights they naturally evoke. 
</tei-p>
               <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-emph data-origname="emph">-<tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Saint-Pierre</tei-placeName>, <tei-date data-origname="date">June 2d</tei-date></tei-emph>.Today the proceedings in  <tei-rs type="event" data-origname="rs" data-origatts="type">the affair of 
                     Grand'Anse</tei-rs>.  The most perfect tranquility reigns in town. Since this morning, a considerable number of soldiers have been stationed around the government palace where the assizes are taking place. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Auguste
                     Eugénie</tei-persName>, accused in absentia in the affair of Grand’Anse, had escaped the investigations of justice by going abroad; he has just appeared in the city of 
 <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Saint-Pierre</tei-placeName>. Saint-Pierre. His friends were at pains to convince him to leave the colony: they demonstrated it was not prudent for him to <tei-pb n="35" facs="v1n2p35" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>be judged at a time when passions were so roiled; that he should better await the judgment in absentia, even if he should present himself later to be judged contradictorily. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Auguste Eugénie</tei-persName> finally decided to leave the colony again and go abroad. </tei-p>
            </tei-div>

            <tei-div type="article" data-origname="div" data-origatts="type">
               <tei-head n="Guadeloupe." data-origname="head" data-origatts="n"><tei-placeName ref="#GP" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">GUADELOUPE.</tei-placeName></tei-head>

               <tei-p data-origname="p">We receive the following from <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">la Pointe-à-Pitre</tei-placeName> :</tei-p>
               <tei-q data-origname="q"><tei-p data-origname="p">Arbitrariness remains the order of the day in our colony; local authorities act as if in a conquered land, allowing one to stay and exiling the other, according to their whim. At the slightest suspicion, a citizen will be hunted down, abducted, deported. 
</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Several discussions having taken place between a young white man named 
                           <tei-persName ref="#ROMA" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Romager-<tei-emph data-origname="emph">the Incorrigible</tei-emph></tei-persName>, and
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Santz</tei-persName>, a young man of color, the mayor and director of the interior ordered <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mrs. Santz</tei-persName>
                      to make her son leave the colony post haste, lest she wanted him arrested and deported by order of the government. Young
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Santz</tei-persName> left for <tei-placeName ref="#HT" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Haiti</tei-placeName>.
                     Can citizens’ freedom be flaunted ever more brazenly!</tei-p></tei-q>
               <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-emph data-origname="emph">-<tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Basse-Terre</tei-placeName>, May 27th.-</tei-emph> The way things are going, we can say without fear of being mistaken, that events such as those that took place in Grand-Anse (<tei-placeName ref="#MQ" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Martinique</tei-placeName>) will happen again, and before long, either here or in <tei-placeName ref="#MQ" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref"> Martinique</tei-placeName>,
                  because aristocracy demands victims, and only among us. Today more than ever, local government does not seek at all to unite the divided classes.</tei-p>
            </tei-div>

            <tei-div type="article" data-origname="div" data-origatts="type">
               <tei-head n="Bourbon." data-origname="head" data-origatts="n"><tei-placeName ref="#BrB" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">BOURBON.</tei-placeName></tei-head>

               <tei-p data-origname="p">While in <tei-placeName ref="#MQ" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Martinique</tei-placeName> and <tei-placeName ref="#GP" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">
                     Guadeloupe</tei-placeName> the colonial aristocracy removes the funds allocated to the budget for public instruction, votes for the removal of mutual schools created by the government, under <tei-persName ref="#AA" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. d'Argout</tei-persName>’s tenure at the ministry of the Navy, and demands the status quo on the condition for slaves be maintained, in <tei-placeName ref="#BrB" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Bourbon</tei-placeName> a colonist of the class we call aristocratic published a pamphlet entitled: 
                   <tei-title data-origname="title">Prospectus for a society of encouragement and emulation for the improvement of the fate of slaves, public instruction, agriculture and the industrial arts. 
</tei-title><tei-pb n="36" facs="v1n2p36" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/></tei-p>
               <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Henri Maingard</tei-persName>, the author, proposes that in each quarter of <tei-placeName ref="#BrB" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Bourbon Island</tei-placeName> be established a society of encouragement, composed of the quarter’s electors. Its goal would be to spread primary education, the best methods of agriculture, in one word, to receive and share all notions useful to all classes of the community. Anyone who has witnessed the pleasing effect of associations can judge in advance how beneficial this one would be. 
</tei-p>
               <tei-p data-origname="p">Here are a few excerpts that irresistibly demonstrate the necessity of societies of encouragement:</tei-p>
               <tei-q data-origname="q"><tei-p data-origname="p">"Where is public spirit on our island? We are unknown to each other; we live in isolation, our talents are buried, our virtues ignored!</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">What are the consequences of the absence of all that gives value and charm to social life? Every foreigner who finds fortune in this land cannot leave it soon enough; love for the homeland does not always resist the disgust of a monotonous life stripped of all that binds man to the soil. </tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">How have we come to such a sad state? In short, we are deprived of the institutions at the source of social wellbeing. Yet what land is more apt to receive institutions of public interest than ours? Our fertile soil and its much sought-after products could easily make comfort reign among us. We have proven that we hold no deep-rooted prejudice. Our intelligent population, enlightened by the reflections European civilization broadcasts from 4000 leagues away, strides towards improvement. It knows its ills, points them out, and demands that they be remedied."</tei-p></tei-q>
            </tei-div>

            <tei-div type="article" data-origname="div" data-origatts="type">
               <tei-head n="Guiana." data-origname="head" data-origatts="n"><tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">GUIANA.</tei-placeName></tei-head>

               <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Persegol</tei-persName>, <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">president of the royal court of 
                        <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Guiana</tei-placeName></tei-roleName>, has just received the wages of the noble independence he demonstrated in his report to the Minister of the Navy on the case of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Vidal de Lingendes</tei-persName> et
                     <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Pontevès</tei-persName>. After facing unwarranted criticism, this honorable magistrate resigned from his positions as member of the colonial council and president of the court.<tei-pb n="37" facs="v1n2p37" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/></tei-p>
               <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. V. Vidal de Lingendes</tei-persName>,
                     <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">attorney general</tei-roleName>, replaced him in the colonial council.</tei-p>
            </tei-div>

            <tei-div type="article" data-origname="div" data-origatts="type">
               <tei-head n="Senegal." data-origname="head" data-origatts="n"><tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">SENEGAL.</tei-placeName></tei-head>
               <tei-p data-origname="p">the presence of English and French cruisers, the slave trade is still practiced all along the coast of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Guinea</tei-placeName>. The Portuguese and the Spaniards engage in this odious traffic more than any others. Two slave traders from these nations were recently captured, but it will be very difficult to prevent cupidity from eluding the law if other governments do not sincerely second 
<tei-placeName ref="#FR" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">France</tei-placeName>
                  and <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">l'Angleterre</tei-placeName>.</tei-p>
            </tei-div>

            <tei-div type="article" data-origname="div" data-origatts="type">
               <tei-head n="Algiers." data-origname="head" data-origatts="n"><tei-placeName ref="#Alg" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">ALGIERS.</tei-placeName></tei-head>

               <tei-p data-origname="p">The following is written about this colony:</tei-p>
               <tei-q data-origname="q"><tei-p data-origname="p">The tribe of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Beni-Moussa</tei-persName>, who live in the mountains, request that their neighbors relinquish the murderer of 
                     <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Aliben-Louié</tei-persName>, who died from a severe injury. He most likely will not be delivered; therefore both parties are preparing for combat. In a different section, a fermentation is currently growing among the tribes in our vicinity, warning signs of which we have seen at the last market in <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">
                        Boufarick
                     </tei-placeName>. The Arabs, who are independent and wary by nature, want neither to be chased after nor pressed, and every time we visit them, while we must generate confidence, we must also be backed by force, the only power they will bow to for years to come. We speak also of faraway coalitions; it is the season, but without nationality, without union, such a knot would as soon be broken as tied, and our weapons be useless to us. Besides, and despite these setbacks we encounter here and there, we have gained considerably in this regard and never since the beginning of the occupation have our affairs been better. 
</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Trade relations between our garrison in
                        <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Bougie</tei-placeName> et les Kabyles des environs. and the local Kabyles have started. They will lead to peace much faster and more safely than our weapons, and we shall do everything in our power to encourage them. The fever in <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Bone
                     </tei-placeName>  is already much less deadly this year than it was in previous years. Sick people in 
                     <tei-placeName ref="#Alg" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Algiers</tei-placeName>, <tei-pb n="38" facs="v1n2p38" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>number barely above 1,200 and, despite the heat, this number remains below all predictions.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Construction at the <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Douera</tei-placeName> camp, at the
                     Mole and in rue de la Marine is in full swing.</tei-p></tei-q>
            </tei-div>

            <tei-div data-origname="div">
                         </tei-div>

            <tei-div data-origname="div">
               <tei-p data-origname="p">We read in <tei-bibl type="periodical" data-origname="bibl" data-origatts="type"><tei-emph data-origname="emph">le Cernéen</tei-emph></tei-bibl>,  a newspaper published in <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Port-Louis</tei-placeName> (<tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">
                  Mauritius</tei-placeName>) :</tei-p>
               <tei-q data-origname="q"><tei-p data-origname="p">"There is talk of introducing 10,000 Indians in this colony. The measure was proposed by a great economist, a man of many projects, with an Indian prince as a financial backer. Word has it that it is bound to be approved by the government and, moreover, by the Port-Louis chamber of commerce. It is also said that, just as the Spaniards once united to expel the Moors from their country, today the Moors join hands to bring Indians in our country. These Indians shall be accompanied and commanded by sepoys, chosen among the troops of the East India Company. These commanders will be allowed to wear their uniforms and other decorations, under the condition that none awaken the frightening memory of the volunteers.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">The planters who will hire these Indians shall be compelled to provide them three meals a day; moreover, they will give them a wage of seven rupees a month, an amount that would seem too high, did we not consider that the inhabitants of Mauritius having to incessantly suffer the competition of Indians in the production of sugar, it must not matter to them to give seven rupees along with food, when in Bengal they give but three rupees without victuals.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">the signal for disorder and laziness for negroes, in short that free labor replace forced labor by means of a reasonable salary. Within the limits of the act of Parliament, this is the goal toward which must tend all local legislative combinations, and on their relative success will depend the more or less flourishing fate of the colony, as well as the maintenance of the prices of securities and property values in the land.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Impressed by, and in fear of, this thought, free negroes take up laboring habits only with difficulty, and offer big plantations but a very precarious resource, so that some people have been considering bringing workers from India, and try again an experience already attempted unsuccessfully, it is true, but which failed so badly perhaps because it was not undertaken properly and judiciously. The main obstacle encountered, which indeed still appears very difficult to overcome, is to obtain from individuals, once transported onto our soil, that they carry out the labor commitment they contracted in their country. Experience has demonstrated that our laws in this regard are insufficient, or did not even contain dispositions that might apply. Would it be possible to establish a law that would perfectly achieve this goal and will the local authority be willing to lend itself to, and participate in its adoption? Such is, it seems to us, the preliminary question that must be asked and resolved before any prudent speculator ventures to undertake such an enterprise.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">As to such a law, that might guarantee both contracting parties the faithful fulfillment of their commitments, one would have to study the subject more than we have, and especially know better the habits, mores and even prejudice of those Indian castes with which it would be proper to deal, to realize whether it is possible to establish it and make it efficient. But, if necessary, there are people here who are capable of providing the exact notions and information sufficient on this point, and it would only be a matter of consulting them. As to the assent or participation of the government, once the first point resolved favorably, as we assume it should be and already is, designed as it is to do all that might contribute to<tei-pb n="40" facs="v1n2p40" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>périté du pays, nous ne voyons pas quelles seraient les objections qui
                     the prosperity of the land, we cannot see what objections could stop it. We point out, however, that more than just the authority’s acquiescence and consent, its material support and active participation will also be needed. Without such certainty, we say it again, it seems unlikely that anyone should want to risk their funds in an attempt of this nature which previously, and partly for this very reason, was so unsuccessful.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">We will go further and say that, were these points conceded, it would still be proper to proceed in this enterprise with all possible circumspection. Thus, it would probably be best undertaken by a company of underwriters using common funds rather than by a single individual. It would not be difficult to find a plantation which has been abandoned for lack of manpower, but where factories remain that can function without major repairs. There could be assigned the number of Indians its exploitation demands; and, neglecting none of the means dictated by a wise economy and good administration, the results obtained after some time could serve as a term of comparison and proof of the success or failure of the experiment. This idea occurs to us because we see in every country that it is by such means of association that the most difficult and most hazardous entreprises are undertaken, that would otherwise be beyond the strength of one single individual, or in which he would not want to risk sums that might jeopardize his fortune were they to fail. Thus, in India, it is through share subscription that regular communication between <tei-placeName ref="#Bng" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Bengal</tei-placeName> and
                        <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Europe</tei-placeName> by way of steamships crossing the isthmus of Suez is being established. At the <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Cape</tei-placeName>,
                     similar means are used to finance the exploration of the interior of Africa; in
                        <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Sainte-Helena</tei-placeName>,  a joint-stock company was founded dedicated to whaling, whales abounding in the surroundings. Everywhere industry develops through such means, and though we have but the merit of imitation, would it not be a great fault on our part to neglect it?</tei-p><tei-pb n="41" facs="v1n2p41" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Until 1829, the local government owned 1294 slaves and 2010 apprentices. They have since freed a number of them. Wondering how many remained, we have tried to find information on this topic. But to our great surprise, we have found out that recent instructions recommend to most rigorously keep secret all administrative matters, including the most trivial. Thus the statistical details that are always provided with zeal by the governments of Europe (even Russia and Prussia) to writers and publicists, are in <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Mauritius</tei-placeName>
                      more occult than the mysteries of Isis. The layman must know nothing of them: the rabble is only good for paying and remaining silent. Still, we cannot but express our surprise that when Parliament proclaims universal emancipation, the government still owns slaves. They will say such are necessary to run the different administrative services: as workers for the civil engineer, as couriers for the police. Very well, then! We are easy to please, as long as we are given some reason. Let the government keep its slaves until it can replace them with free employees. 
</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">But the apprentices! It has no use for them. Every customs collector has indentured them out to his friends, or to protegees of power, some for 14 years, others for 7. Certainly there can only be a few whose time has not expired. What then prevents them from enjoying the freedom guaranteed them by law? Oh! It is that most have been placed with government employees who find it very convenient to have good servants for 2 piasters a month. But that is illegal and unfair to these poor people. Enemies of all forms of oppression, we are not afraid to raise our voices in their favor. They all know a trade and are capable of earning a living: their masters, in receiving them, vowed to teach them. Once free, they should be no burden to society and should make a peaceful living of their industry. Should they misbehave, repressive laws exist for them and other freedmen. May they therefore be released, at the risk of letting Mr. So-and-so take expensive domestic workers in their stead."</tei-p></tei-q>
               <tei-pb n="42" facs="v1n2p42" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
            </tei-div>

            <tei-div type="article" data-origname="div" data-origatts="type">
               <tei-head n="Grenada." data-origname="head" data-origatts="n"><tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">GRENADA.</tei-placeName></tei-head>

               <tei-p data-origname="p"> A letter from <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Saint-Georges</tei-placeName> tells us:</tei-p>
               <tei-q data-origname="q"><tei-p data-origname="p">"Everyone is making preparations for the big change that must occur on the First of August. Even those who until now had shown themselves the warmest supporters of slavery, seeing their cupidity satisfied in the part they shall receive of the twenty million pounds sterling of indemnity allocated them by England, now seem delighted to no longer bear the title of slave owners."</tei-p></tei-q>
            </tei-div>

            <tei-div type="article" data-origname="div" data-origatts="type">
               <tei-head n="Tortola." data-origname="head" data-origatts="n"><tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">TORTOLA.</tei-placeName></tei-head>

               <tei-p data-origname="p">In this English possession, they did not wait for the date fixed by the bill to proclaim the freedom of negroes. The inhabitants, understanding all that this law contains of high morality, hastened to enforce it.</tei-p>
            </tei-div>

            <tei-div type="article" data-origname="div" data-origatts="type">
               <tei-head n="Demerara" data-origname="head" data-origatts="n"><tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">DEMERARA</tei-placeName></tei-head>

               <tei-p data-origname="p">In the English colonies, reason triumphs more every day over the odious and ridiculous skin prejudice. In <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Demerara</tei-placeName>,
                  an establishment neighboring <tei-placeName ref="#GF" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">French Guiana</tei-placeName>, the bill
                  abolishing slavery only drew the different classes of the population closer together: all distinction of color has entirely disappeared. According to the account of a traveler recently arrived in this colony, people of color, contrary to creoles, occupy liberal professions that were until now unjustly forbidden to them; they are allowed to become officers in the militias, and it seems that the English government, which without much resistance joins in the progress of civilization, will one day or the other allow them to hold public office. This equitable measure would complete the entire fusion of the two classes.</tei-p>
               <tei-p data-origname="p"> At a ball given by the governor of Demerara, a great number of ladies of color stood out by their wit and education to this same traveler. In general, in English possessions, the colored class has understood that the most efficient means for them to reach a perfect, and
<tei-pb n="43" facs="v1n2p43" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>real equality among the population in the colonies, was to indulge in the study of science and letters, and thus put themselves in a state to compete with the white class. This is a model we cannot but recommend to the attention of our brethren in the French colonies.</tei-p>
            </tei-div>

            <tei-div type="article" data-origname="div" data-origatts="type">
               <tei-head n="Cuba" data-origname="head" data-origatts="n"><tei-placeName ref="#CUB" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">CUBA</tei-placeName></tei-head>

               <tei-p data-origname="p">Acts of piracy have been committed in the vicinity of Honduras and Nicaragua (New Spain). Two suspicious ships of Spanish make were recently spotted sailing near Carthagena, along a ship believed to be French, which they probably captured. The government of Jamaica sent a few war sloops in pursuit.</tei-p>
               <tei-p data-origname="p">The slave trade occurs in the open in Havana, despite the dangers those who engage in it should face. Last April, a slaver having dropped sail on the West coast of Saint Domingue, some of the slaves broke their fetters, seized weapons, and after a terrible melee during which the crew was beaten, they took over the ship, which soon sunk. Those negroes who did not drown were welcome in Saint-Domingue. Five or six sailors escaped to Cuba.</tei-p>
            </tei-div>

            <tei-div type="article" data-origname="div" data-origatts="type">
               <tei-head n="Canada" data-origname="head" data-origatts="n"><tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">CANADA</tei-placeName></tei-head>

               <tei-p data-origname="p">We read the following observations on Canada’s political customs in the <tei-bibl type="periodical" data-origname="bibl" data-origatts="type">Journal de la Marine</tei-bibl>:</tei-p>
               <tei-q data-origname="q"><tei-p data-origname="p">n Canada, women have the privilege to vote in elections the same as men. In the last elections, where <tei-persName data-origname="persName">
                       Colonel Baley</tei-persName>  was nominated to the legislature, as there was competition between
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Litte</tei-persName> et <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Wilkinson</tei-persName>, no fewer than thirty-five ladies attended the hustings to cast a vote in his favor. These ladies were widows or Misses. It was noted that only one married woman voted, probably encouraged by the others. However, it often happens that the wife will vote one way and the husband the other, in the same or different elections, following the rights granted them through property. In the month of May 1832, there was a contest to the Montreal election, which lasted about
<tei-pb n="44" facs="v1n2p44" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>a month, during which two hundred and twenty-five women voted. One of the candidates was an Irishman; ninety-five ladies voted for him. The other gentleman was <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr.
                        Stanlez-Bagg</tei-persName>, citizen of the <tei-placeName ref="#USA" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">États-Unis</tei-placeName>,
                     naturalized in <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Canada</tei-placeName>;a hundred and four women voted for him. The other twenty-six women who showed up did not use their political rights. On this occasion, several ladies took a party contrary to that which their husbands had embraced; the latter did not mind.</tei-p></tei-q>
            </tei-div>

            <tei-div type="article" data-origname="div" data-origatts="type">
               <tei-head n="Cprocession for the Young Pavillon." data-origname="head" data-origatts="n">CPROCESSION FOR THE YOUNG PAVILLON.</tei-head>

               <tei-p data-origname="p">On July 25, we attended the funeral service for <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Sainte-Cour
                     Pavillon</tei-persName>, of <tei-placeName ref="#GP" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Guadeloupe</tei-placeName>, Sainte-Cour Pavillon of Guadeloupe, a student at Henri IV high school who gave much promise. A great number of people of color attended this ceremony. The presence of a delegation of young European schoolmates of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Pavillon</tei-persName>.
                  Un jeune camarade de <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Pavillon</tei-persName>, <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr.
                     Dorville-Jouannet</tei-persName>,  man of color, law student, uttered the following words at his friend’s grave: 
</tei-p>
               <tei-q data-origname="q"><tei-p data-origname="p">"So it is done, dear Pavillon; merciless Death has placed her frozen hand on your sixteen year-old brow. Barely did she allow an interval between your cradle and your grave. You came to <tei-placeName ref="#FR" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">France</tei-placeName>
                     seeking the instruction that shall bring emancipation to men of color, and after a ten-year stay, as you were finishing rhetorics, as you were about to start a career whose usefulness is recognized by all, cruel Death stopped you.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"> Pity be upon you, unfortunate compatriot, if, as we believe, your heart beat for your brethren! If sometimes you blushed with indignation thinking of the horrible yoke that weighs upon your miserable class! It would have been so sweet for you to contribute to the renewal of your country, to make it worthy of the nineteenth century, to make it renounce the stupid and barbaric prejudice of the past! Then, you could have died; but today is too soon!</tei-p><tei-pb n="45" facs="v1n2p45" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">What words of comfort shall we have your father hear? What shall we tell your people, this aunt who could have made you forget your mother, if a mother could be forgotten? Ah! Descend a while from the abode of departed souls, and dictate for us the words that might temper their pain, for this task is beyond our powers.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Adieu! Rest in peace, dear Pavillon, and for lack of your native land, may the French earth be light upon thee!</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Adieu! Adieu forever!</tei-p></tei-q>
            </tei-div>

            <tei-div xml:id="biography" id="biography" data-origname="div" data-origatts="xml:id">
               <tei-head n="Biography." data-origname="head" data-origatts="n">BIOGRAPHY.</tei-head>
               <tei-head n="M. Cabasse." data-origname="head" data-origatts="n">M. CABASSE.</tei-head>

               <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Prosper Cabasse</tei-persName>, former attorney general to the royal court of <tei-placeName ref="#GP" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Guadeloupe</tei-placeName>, n'intéresse les colonies que
                  s of interest to the colonies solely for the role he played there during the Restoration, notably in the infamous trial of the men of color from <tei-placeName ref="#MQ" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref"> Martinique.</tei-placeName></tei-p>
               <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Prosper Cabasse</tei-persName> is a living example of what weakness allied to ambition can do. Without precisely possessing a vile and evil soul, with an easy and soft temperament, nevertheless this man, so eager to succeed, embraced with warmth the cause of the restored Bourbons and made himself into the humble servant of the counter-revolutionary reaction they ordered.</tei-p>
               <tei-p data-origname="p">A small lawyer living in obscurity in Aix, he wanted to become someone; he so stridently showed off his love for this family of public enemies that had imposed foreign bayonets onto <tei-placeName ref="#FR" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">France</tei-placeName>
                   spoke so often and so loudly of his royalism, that the small lawyer became a magistrate. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Cabasse</tei-persName> was president of the criminal court of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Toulon</tei-placeName> 
                  when selected jurors condemned to death <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Captain
                     Vallée</tei-persName>, this hero who died with all the courage and composure of a martyr to freedom. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Cabasse</tei-persName>  owed to this circumstance to be noticed by his superiors and noted as a zealous man who should be promoted. He also owed it, according to public opinion, the 
<tei-pb n="46" facs="v1n2p46" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>shiny red ribbon he wears on his lapel. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr.
                     Cabasse</tei-persName>  will argue that there is a mistake and that this is not why he received this decoration. That may well be; but, as he does not deny that he was decorated after the sentencing of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Vallée</tei-persName>,
                public opinion greatly presumes. It is said on this topic that not long after this, one of his friends, having come across Cabasse as he wore the red ribbon, grabbed him by his lapel, and with a snarky tone greeted him with the Latin word <tei-foreign data-origname="foreign"><tei-emph data-origname="emph">vale</tei-emph></tei-foreign>. 
                 In 1826, this magistrate was put in direct contact with the colonies. Named attorney general to <tei-placeName ref="#GP" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Guadeloupe</tei-placeName> by
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Minister Chabrol</tei-persName>, <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr.
                     Cabasse</tei-persName>, having courted the powerful in Paris, went to
                     <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Brest</tei-placeName>, Brest, where a frigate of the royal navy was waiting for him.
                     <tei-persName ref="#CB" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. Bissette</tei-persName>, <tei-persName ref="#LFab" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. Fabien</tei-persName> et
                     <tei-persName ref="#JBVol" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. Volny</tei-persName>, the great propagandists, were detained in it. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Cabasse</tei-persName> was to be their accuser. They wrote an address to him in order to enlighten him and, having asked the new attorney general for a reply, he, taking already the airs of a grandee so well fitting his new position, cavalierly sent his footman to tell them he had received their letter.</tei-p>
               <tei-p data-origname="p">After landing in <tei-placeName ref="#MQ" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Martinique</tei-placeName>  and exchanging with the most influential members of the colonial aristocracy there, the new attorney general arrived in January 1827 at the seat of his jurisdiction.</tei-p>
               <tei-p data-origname="p">On March 27, 1827, the case of <tei-persName ref="#CB" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Messrs. Bissette</tei-persName>,
                     <tei-persName ref="#LFab" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Fabien</tei-persName> et <tei-persName ref="#JBVol" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Volny</tei-persName>  came to the royal court of 
                     <tei-placeName ref="#GP" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Guadeloupe</tei-placeName>. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Cabasse</tei-persName>, supported the accusation with a long indictment written in the dragging, florid style replete with classical reminiscences so typical of mediocre lawyers, the scourge of auditors and the punishment of bad judges. To say that he did so relentlessly and passionately would be unfair. It was worse: coldly, emotionlessly, he spoke for three hours. After flattering the prejudices of the colonial aristocracy and striving to create culprits where there only were men who used their rights against bold dominators; after invoking royal ordinances two centuries old, and quoting from <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Moulins</tei-persName>’s ordinance these terrible words: “whosoever posts or circulates seditious or libelous pamphlets will be hanged and strangled until dead;” and these no less horrible words from the ordinance of January 1629:</tei-p>
               <tei-pb n="47" facs="v1n2p47" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
               <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-q data-origname="q"><tei-emph data-origname="emph">"Whosoever writes, prints, presents for sale, publishes or distributes books, pamphlets or writings libelous or insulting will be hanged and strangled until dead"</tei-emph></tei-q> ; he concluded mildly, contrary to the law and as if frightened by the odious consequences of his own requisitory against <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Bissette</tei-persName>,
                  requesting ten years of exile. Guilty or innocent, there was no other alternative: if guilty, the hideous application of the text of the ordinance he had invoked–<tei-emph data-origname="emph">death</tei-emph> –should have been requested; if innocent, Bissette should have been acquitted. The middle ground Mr. Cabasse sought, outside of the formal provisions of the law, was invented only to bring about a conviction; it would have been too revolting to sentence a man to death for circulating what these gentlemen called a pamphlet; they would not have dared.
                  Mr. Cabasse’s mezzo-termine allowed them to satisfy the evil passions of their <tei-placeName ref="#MQ" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref"> Martinique</tei-placeName> colleagues; but motivating a decision contrary to the law was going to be difficult. This is why it took the judges five hours to deliver their verdict. </tei-p>
               <tei-p data-origname="p">No sooner was <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Bissette</tei-persName> sentenced that, by one of those turns that become the character of those men who would please everyone, Mr. Cabasse paid a visit to the exile in his prison at ten in the evening, and strove to impart on him the softness of his conviction, telling him not to resent him, that he could not do better; living in France was not too hard, and he begged him to have regard for his good intentions. As one might imagine, Mr. Bissette showed very little gratitude to the attorney general for his visit, inspired as it evidently was by his fear of metropolitan opinion.</tei-p>
               <tei-p data-origname="p">The attorney general’s conduct in this affair was full of bad faith and weakness; he went as far as to unseal letters sent from Paris to the defendants by their lawyer, letters registered to himself. The servant of the elevated classes–that is the whites–, as he called them in his indictment, he served no less civil servants who should have followed his orders. The police commissioner, <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Hercule-Petit-Lolo</tei-persName>,an inept man and henchman of the aristocracy of the skin, transgressed and even tore up his orders when they went against the passions of the dominators, and the attorney general let it happen, humiliating himself in the face of this subaltern agent’s 
 <tei-pb n="48" facs="v1n2p48" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>will. Thus the parents and friends of the inmates, despite the authorization signed by the attorney general, were several times refused entrance into the prison, because it so pleased this police commissioner not to let them inside. The just complaints made by prisoners to the attorney general about the ill treatment they received always remained unanswered. This is the way this man behaved in the exercise of his ministry, joining laziness to the spirit of injustice and servility. To cite but one fact: 
                     <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Bisette</tei-persName> having requested release on bail so he could see his family and settle his affairs before leaving, <tei-persName data-origname="persName">governor
                     Desrotours</tei-persName> and even the colonist judges who had sentenced him consented to it: <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Cabasse</tei-persName> alone opposed it.</tei-p>
               <tei-p data-origname="p">
On his return to France in 1829, he was named attorney general in Limoges. Then came the July Revolution. Mr. Cabasse felt tremors in his public accuser’s seat. A lover of his position before all, he addressed the new minister to be kept in it, and in support of his request, he had the inconceivable idea to produce his famous indictment as a testimony of his moderation. 
 But the friends of the deportees from <tei-placeName ref="#MQ" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Martinique</tei-placeName>,
                   surrounding the virtuous <tei-persName ref="#Dupo" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Dupont de
                    l'Eure</tei-persName>, proved they had memory: Mr. Cabasse was dismissed.</tei-p>
               <tei-p data-origname="p">He has since sought a new position in vain, trying even to be reappointed in the colonies. We cannot imagine there will ever be a minister of the Navy indecent enough to send him back. Rejected from public office, Mr. Cabasse has become an agent for the pope and for the Legitimist party; it is said that he schemes for the Holy See. May God hold him in his holy glory!
</tei-p>
               <tei-p data-origname="p">IMPRIMERIE D'HERHAN, 580, RUE SAINT-DENIS. <!--BAS DE PAGE-->
               </tei-p>
            </tei-div>
            </tei-div>

      </tei-body>

            <tei-persName xml:lang="en" lang="en" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="xml:lang">William Lamb, 2nd Viscount Melbourne</tei-persName>

                <tei-p data-origname="p">William Lamb, 2nd Viscount Melbourne, was twice prime minister of the United Kingdom: first for four months in 1834, corresponding to the first issues of the <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Revue des Colonies</tei-emph>, then again from 1835 to 1841. Like many members of the Whig party at the time, he was an ardent defender of the institution of slavery, strongly opposing the 1833 abolition bill.</tei-p>

                                        <tei-p data-origname="p">William Lamb, deuxième vicomte de Melbourne, exerce à deux reprises la fonction de Premier ministre du Royaume-Uni : d'abord durant quatre mois en 1834, période correspondant aux premiers numéros de la <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Revue des Colonies</tei-emph>, puis de 1835 à 1841. Comme de nombreux membres du parti <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Whig </tei-emph>de l’époque, il se montre un fervent défenseur de l’institution de l’esclavage et s’oppose fermement au projet de loi sur l’abolition de 1833.</tei-p>

            </tei-note>

        <tei-person xml:id="ROMA" id="ROMA" data-origname="person" data-origatts="xml:id">
            <tei-persName xml:lang="en" lang="en" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="xml:lang">Romagé the Ungovernable</tei-persName>
            <tei-persName xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="xml:lang">Romagé l'Inregigible</tei-persName>
            <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="Person" resp="#jessica" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type xml:lang">
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Romagé, also known as Romager, was one of the central figures in a series of dueling incidents that took place between white Creole colonists and free people of color in the colonies during the 1830s. These frequent clashes between the two groups were fueled by both personal disputes and collective solidarities.  </tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">At the end of 1833, on the evening of November 3, Romagé, while returning from a performance, is said to have confronted a man of color. The altercation that ensued reportedly led to a significant gathering of free people of color. In the following days, tensions continued to escalate, resulting in multiple arrests, including that of Romagé.  </tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">The colonial authorities, specifically the Private Council of Guadeloupe, ultimately decided to banish those deemed responsible for instigating these disturbances from the canton of Pointe-à-Pitre. Romagé was among them and was placed under surveillance on the island of La Désirade.</tei-p>
                <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl">Adélaïde-Merlande, Jacques, " Libres et affranchis - réformes et tensions " in  <tei-title data-origname="title">Historial Antillais</tei-title>  , Tome III, Dajani éditions, Pointe-à-Pitre, 1981 pp. 287-307</tei-bibl>
            </tei-note>
            <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="Person" resp="#jessica" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type xml:lang">
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Romagé ou Romager est l’un des protagonistes de l’une des affaires de duels survenues entre les colons blancs créoles des colonies et libres de couleur dans les années 1830. Les incidents entre les deux groupes qui se multiplient mêlent conflits personnels et solidarités de groupes. À la fin de l’année 1833, dans la soirée du 3 novembre, Romagé, rentrant du spectacle, aurait apostrophé un homme de couleur. L’altercation qui s’en suivit aurait entraîné un rassemblement considérable de libres de couleur. Dans les jours qui suivent, les conflits se poursuivent et donnent lieu à plusieurs arrestations, dont Romagé. Les autorités, en l’occurrence le Conseil Privé, de la Guadeloupe, décident d’exclure du canton de Pointe-à-Pitre ceux qui avaient été à l’origine de ces altercations. C’est le cas de Romagé mis en surveillance à la Désirade. </tei-p>
                <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl">Adélaïde-Merlande, Jacques, « Libres et affranchis - réformes et tensions » dans  <tei-title data-origname="title">Historial Antillais</tei-title>  , Tome III, Dajani éditions, Pointe-à-Pitre, 1981 pp. 287-307</tei-bibl>
            </tei-note>
        </tei-person>
        <tei-person xml:id="CIC" id="CIC" data-origname="person" data-origatts="xml:id">
            <tei-persName xml:lang="en" lang="en" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="xml:lang">Cicéron, Louis Marie Ambroise Dieudonné</tei-persName>
            <tei-persName xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="xml:lang">Cicéron, Louis Marie Ambroise Dieudonné</tei-persName>
            <tei-birth data-origname="birth">1797</tei-birth>
            <tei-death data-origname="death">1870</tei-death>
            <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="Person" resp="#abel" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type xml:lang">
                <tei-p data-origname="p">The son of Ambroise Cicéron, a white Guadeloupean Creole notary,and Marie Victoire Artaud, Louis Marie Ambroise Dieudonné Cicéron was born in Saint-Pierre on September 25, 1797 and died on April 11, 1870 in the same city. He began practicing law in 1821, earned a bachelor of arts degree in 1822, became a lawyer and proprietor in 1825, was admitted to the royal court of Martinique and the court of 1era authority of Saint-Pierre in 1827, and was, between 1843 and 1844, a  colonial advisor and member of the municipal council of Saint-Pierre. As a defender of slavery, Ciceron was a political enemy of Cyrille Bissette through the 1830s; in October 1834, the two dueled in the Bois de Vincennes. Their political enmity is perceptible in several articles by Ciceron published in Journal du Havre in 1831, widely repeated in his “Petition to the King, to the nation and to the chambers” (dated January 1, 1832). Bissette responded to him in a letter dated May 15, 1833. In 1844, Cicero, present in Paris, acted as rapporteur for the “Observations of a special commission of the Colonial Council of Martinique on the bill presented on May 14 to the Chamber of Peers.”. These observations, signed by Le Pelletier-Duclary, president of the Colonial Council, concerned a bill for the abolition of slavery in the French colonies, refuting it point by point. Bissette's apparent good will towards former enslavers after the abolition of May 1848, and his association with the colonist Pécoul around legislative elections of 1849, brought him closer to Ciceron, whom he visited upon his return to Martinique on March 20, 1849.</tei-p>
            </tei-note>
            <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="Person" resp="#abel" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type xml:lang">
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Fils du notaire blanc créole guadeloupéen, Ambroise Cicéron et de Marie Victoire Artaud, Louis Marie Ambroise Dieudonné Cicéron est né à Saint-Pierre le 25 septembre 1797 et meurt le 11 avril 1870 en la même ville. Il est qualifié de praticien en 1821, étudiant en droit bachelier ès lettres (1822), avocat et propriétaire (1825), avocat avoué près la cour royale de la Martinique et le tribunal de 1ère instance de Saint-Pierre (1827), conseiller colonial, membre du conseil municipal de Saint-Pierre et propriétaire en cette ville (1843-1844). Partisan du maintien du système esclavagiste, Louis Cicéron est opposé à Cyrille Bissette durant les années 1830-1840. Il se bat d’ailleurs en duel en octobre 1834 avec Bissette au bois de Vincennes. Leur inimitié politique est perceptible dans plusieurs articles de Cicéron publiés au journal du Havre en 1831, repris largement dans sa “Pétition au Roi, à la nation et aux chambres” (datée du 1er janvier 1832). Bissette lui répond dans une lettre du 15 mai 1833 ensuite. En 1844, Cicéron, présent à Paris, se fait le rapporteur des “Observations d’une commission spéciale du Conseil colonial de la Martinique sur le projet de loi présenté le 14 mai dernier à la Chambre des Pairs. Paris : Impr. de Bruneau, 1844”. Ces “observations, signées de Le Pelletier-Duclary, président du Conseil colonial, portaient sur le projet de loi du 14 mai 1844, visant à l’abolition de l’esclavage dans les colonies françaises, et le réfutant article après article...”. Le retournement de veste de Bissette vis-à-vis des colons esclavagistes après l’abolition de l’esclavage en mai 1848, son association avec le colon Pécoul en vue des élections législatives de 1849, le fit se rapprocher de Cicéron qu’il visita dès son arrivée en Martinique le 20 mars 1849.</tei-p>
            </tei-note>
        </tei-person>
        <tei-person xml:id="LePell" id="LePell" data-origname="person" data-origatts="xml:id">
            <tei-persName xml:lang="en" lang="en" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="xml:lang">Jean-Baptiste François Le Pelletier-Duclary</tei-persName>
            <tei-persName xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="xml:lang">Jean-Baptiste François Le Pelletier-Duclary</tei-persName>
            <tei-birth data-origname="birth">1791 or 1793</tei-birth>
            <tei-death data-origname="death">1865</tei-death>
            <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="Person" resp="#abel" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type xml:lang">
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Lawyer at the court of Paris, assessor to the Superior Council of Martinique (took offic 1819), councilor to the Royal Court of Martinique (May 9, 1821, confirmed October 5 1828), of which he became president in January 1835, knight of the Legion of Honor (January 16, 1836), president of the Colonial Council of Martinique from 1834 to 1838 and from 1839 to 1847. He married Marie Elisabeth Nelly Cornette de Saint-Cyr, a white Creole woman on June 11, 1821 in Case Pilote. Like many white settlers, he refused any reformation of the slave system, particularly in favor of equality for free people of color. He was one of the members of the Assize Court of Saint-Pierre chaired by de Perinelle who judged the 173 individuals accused during the Grande Anse affair (Lorrain) of December 1833. He shared quite naturally the prejudices and principles inherent in the mentality and social group of the powerful white families of the colony who made up the colonial judiciary between the decades of 1820 and 1840. </tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">
                </tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">https://www.patrimoines-martinique.org/ark:/35569/w6lcx297j5p0/c1f43fd7-b3e2-4d32-b04f-d620bbbbf54e</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">https://man8rove.com/en/profile/eql4p4vv1-jean-baptiste-francois-le-pelletier-du-clary</tei-p>
            </tei-note>
            <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="Person" resp="#abel" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type xml:lang">
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Né le 26 décembre 1791 ou le 28 janvier 1793 à Case-Pilote en Martinique selon les sources consultées, décédé le 12 juillet 1865 à Case-Pilote, habitant propriétaire domicilié dans cette paroisse et quartier, avocat à la cour de Paris, assesseur au Conseil supérieur de la Martinique en fonctions en 1819, conseiller à la Cour royale de la Martinique (9 mai 1821, confirmé le 5 octobre 1828) dont il est président en janvier 1835, chevalier de la légion d’honneur (16 janvier 1836), président du Conseil colonial de la Martinique de 1834 à 1838 et de 1839 à 1847. Il épouse à Case-Pilote, Marie Elisabeth Nelly Cornette de Saint-Cyr, blanche créole, le 11 juin 1821. Il est l’incarnation même des colons, blancs créoles, refusant toute évolution du système esclavagiste notamment en faveur de l’égalité pour les libres de couleur. Il fait partie des membres de la Cour d’assises de Saint-Pierre présidée par de Perinelle qui juge au début du mois de juin 1834 les 173 individus accusés lors de l’affaire de la Grande Anse (Lorrain) en décembre 1833. Il partage tout naturellement les préjugés et les principes inhérents à la mentalité et au groupe social des grandes familles blanches de la colonie qui composent la magistrature coloniale entre les décennies 1820 et 1840.</tei-p>

                </tei-p>

        <tei-person xml:id="MACK" id="MACK" data-origname="person" data-origatts="xml:id">
            <tei-persName xml:lang="en" lang="en" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="xml:lang">Ange René Armand, baron de Mackau</tei-persName>
            <tei-persName xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="xml:lang">Ange René Armand, baron de Mackau</tei-persName>
            <tei-birth data-origname="birth">1788</tei-birth>
            <tei-death data-origname="death">1855</tei-death>
            <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="Person" resp="#chelsea" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type xml:lang">
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Baron Ange-René-Armand de Mackau had a long career in the navy in various French colonies. He was chosen as Charles X’s envoy to Haiti to deliver—backed by a fleet of 14 warships—the 1825 ordonnance to Haitian president Jean-Pierre Boyer. He later became minister of the navy and colonies. In his new role, he proposed set of gradualist laws in anticipation of the abolition of slavery in the French colonies. The 1845 Mackau laws, as they came to be known, improved conditions for the enslaved, promoted their access to religious instruction, and allowed for the practice of buying one’s freedom or the freedom of one’s kin (<tei-emph data-origname="emph">rachat</tei-emph>). Though many lauded the laws, Bissette attacked the laws swiftly and vehemently in his writings for their gradualist approach. </tei-p>
                <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl">Dorigny, Marcel; Bruffaerts, Jean-Claude; Gaillard, Gusti-Klara; and Théodat, Jean-Marie, eds.,  <tei-title data-origname="title">Haïti-France. Les chaînes de la dette. Le rapport Mackau (1825)</tei-title>  . Hémisphères Éditions, 2022.</tei-bibl>
                <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl">Jennings, Lawrence C.  <tei-title data-origname="title">French Anti-Slavery: The Movement for the Abolition of Slavery in France, 1802-1848</tei-title> . Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2000. 29-37, 49-50, 71-73, 266-69.</tei-bibl>
                <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl">Schmidt, Nelly.  <tei-title data-origname="title">Abolitionnistes de l'esclavage et réformateurs des colonies, 1820-1851: analyses et documents</tei-title> . Paris: Karthala, 2000.</tei-bibl>
            </tei-note>
            <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="Person" resp="#chelsea" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type xml:lang">
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Le baron Ange-René-Armand de Mackau fait carrière dans la marine et exerce diverses fonctions dans les colonies françaises. Il est choisi comme émissaire de Charles X auprès d’Haïti pour remettre, à la tête d’une flotte de quatorze navires de guerre, l’ordonnance de 1825 au président haïtien Jean-Pierre Boyer. Par la suite, il devient ministre de la Marine et des Colonies. À ce poste, il propose une série de lois réformistes en prévision de l’abolition de l’esclavage dans les colonies françaises. Les lois Mackau de 1845, comme elles seront appelées, visent à améliorer les conditions de vie des personnes réduites en esclavage, à favoriser leur accès à l’instruction religieuse et à encadrer la possibilité de rachat, leur permettant ainsi d’acheter leur liberté ou celle de leurs proches. Si ces mesures sont largement saluées, Bissette les condamne avec vigueur dans ses écrits, dénonçant leur gradualisme.</tei-p>
                <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl">Dorigny, Marcel; Bruffaerts, Jean-Claude; Gaillard, Gusti-Klara; et Théodat, Jean-Marie, eds.,  <tei-title data-origname="title">Haïti-France. Les chaînes de la dette. Le rapport Mackau (1825)</tei-title>  . Hémisphères Éditions, 2022.</tei-bibl>
                <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl">Jennings, Lawrence C.  <tei-title data-origname="title">French Anti-Slavery: The Movement for the Abolition of Slavery in France, 1802-1848</tei-title> . Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2000. 29-37, 49-50, 71-73, 266-69.</tei-bibl>
                <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl">Schmidt, Nelly.  <tei-title data-origname="title">Abolitionnistes de l'esclavage et réformateurs des colonies, 1820-1851: analyses et documents</tei-title> . Paris: Karthala, 2000.</tei-bibl>
            </tei-note>
        </tei-person>
        <tei-person xml:id="RS" id="RS" data-origname="person" data-origatts="xml:id">
            <tei-persName xml:lang="en" lang="en" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="xml:lang">Rosily, Viscount of</tei-persName>
            <tei-persName xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="xml:lang">Rosily, vicomte de</tei-persName>
            <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="Person" resp="#abel" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type xml:lang">
                <tei-p data-origname="p" data-empty=""/>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Viscount Rosily served as Director of the Interior in Martinique at the time of the Grande Anse affair in December 1833, which was later tried by the Court of Assizes in Saint-Pierre in June 1834. As such, he was responsible for the administration of the island, overseeing matters ranging from general and sanitary policing to the management of direct and indirect taxation.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">He is mentioned in the <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Revue des Colonies</tei-emph> because Cyrille Bissette, in 1834, directly accused the colonial authorities—Governor Dupotet, Director of the Interior Rosily, the district commander of Grande Anse, Desabaye, and the commander of the Saint-Pierre garrison, de Montigny—calling for the prosecution of these four men.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">In the Pointe-à-Pitre affair described in the first issue of the <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Revue des Colonies</tei-emph>, viscount Rosily advocated for the expulsion of the accused individuals who were free. However, he was more reluctant when it came to expelling enslaved individuals accused of various offenses, such as marronage or poisoning. He viewed the deportation of enslaved people as a potential danger to the colony, arguing that such measures might encourage others to commit crimes.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">
                </tei-p>
                <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl">Pâme, Stella.  <tei-title data-origname="title">Cyrille Bissette: un martyr de la liberté</tei-title> . Fort-de-France, Martinique: Editions Désormeaux, 1999.</tei-bibl>
                <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl">Oudin Bastide, Caroline,  <tei-title data-origname="title">Des nègres et des juges : La scandaleuse affaire Spoutourne (1831-1834)</tei-title>   <tei-emph data-origname="emph">, </tei-emph> Paris, Editions Complexe, 2008</tei-bibl>
            </tei-note>
            <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="Person" resp="#abel" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type xml:lang">
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Le vicomte de Rosily est directeur de l’Intérieur en Martinique au moment de l’affaire de la Grande Anse, survenue en décembre 1833 et jugée par la Cour d’assises de Saint-Pierre en juin 1834. À ce titre, il est chargé de l’administration de l’île, ses attributions couvrant aussi bien la police générale et sanitaire que la gestion des contributions directes et indirectes.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">S’il est mentionné dans la <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Revue des Colonies</tei-emph>, c’est parce que Cyrille Bissette, en 1834, accuse directement les autorités coloniales de complicité et réclame la mise en accusation de quatre hauts responsables : le gouverneur Dupotet, le directeur de l’Intérieur Rosily, le commandant du quartier de la Grande Anse, Desabaye, et le commandant de la garnison de Saint-Pierre, de Montigny.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Dans l’affaire de Pointe-à-Pitre, relatée dans le premier numéro de la <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Revue des Colonies</tei-emph>, le vicomte de Rosily se prononce en faveur de l’expulsion des accusés libres. Toutefois, il se montre plus réservé quant à l’exil des esclaves impliqués dans divers délits, tels que le marronnage ou l’empoisonnement. Selon lui, la déportation des esclaves constitue une menace pour la colonie, car une telle mesure pourrait les encourager à commettre d’autres crimes.</tei-p>
                <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl">Pâme, Stella.  <tei-title data-origname="title">Cyrille Bissette: un martyr de la liberté</tei-title> . Fort-de-France, Martinique: Editions Désormeaux, 1999.</tei-bibl>
                <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl">Oudin Bastide, Caroline,  <tei-title data-origname="title">Des nègres et des juges : La scandaleuse affaire Spoutourne (1831-1834)</tei-title>   <tei-emph data-origname="emph">, </tei-emph> Paris, Editions Complexe, 2008</tei-bibl>
            </tei-note>
        </tei-person>

        <tei-person xml:id="Mul" id="Mul" data-origname="person" data-origatts="xml:id">
            <tei-persName xml:lang="en" lang="en" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="xml:lang">Phipps, Constantine, The Earl of Mulgrave</tei-persName>
            <tei-persName xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="xml:lang">Phipps, Constantine, comte de Mulgrave</tei-persName>
            <tei-birth data-origname="birth">1797</tei-birth>
            <tei-death data-origname="death">1863</tei-death>
            <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="Person" resp="#masha" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type xml:lang">
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Constantine Phipps, known successively as 1st Marquess of Normanby, Viscount Normanby, and The Earl of Mulgrave was a Whig politician who served as Governor of Jamaica from 1832-1834, Lord Lieutenant of Ireland from 1835 to 1839 and Home Secretary from 1839 to 1841.</tei-p>
            </tei-note>
            <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="Person" resp="#masha" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type xml:lang">
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Constantine Phipps, premier marquis de Normanby, également vicomte de Normanby et comte de Mulgrave, est une figure politique majeure du parti <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Whig</tei-emph>. De 1832 à 1834, il exerce les fonctions de gouverneur de la Jamaïque, avant de devenir Lord Lieutenant d'Irlande de 1835 à 1839, puis secrétaire d'État à l'Intérieur de 1839 à 1841.</tei-p>
            </tei-note>
        </tei-person>
        <tei-person xml:id="ANog" id="ANog" data-origname="person" data-origatts="xml:id">
            <tei-persName xml:lang="en" lang="en" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="xml:lang">Nogues, Arsène</tei-persName>
            <tei-persName xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="xml:lang">Nogues, Arsène</tei-persName>
            <tei-birth data-origname="birth">1798</tei-birth>
            <tei-death data-origname="death">1869</tei-death>
            <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="Person" resp="#abel" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type xml:lang">
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Born in Redon on June 12, 1798, Arsene Nogues held various positions in Brest and Nancy and was also attorney general in Guadeloupe then in Martinique during the 1830s. Later, he was advisor to the royal court of Rouen in 1845. Married to the daughter of a coffee merchant and planter of Guadeloupean origin, Jean Joseph Albert Chaviteau, who settled in Cuba at the beginning of the 19th century, Nogues had strong ties to the planter community. Nogues represented the public prosecutor as attorney general during the Grande Anse affair in December 1833. The indictment prepared by Nogues in June 1834, recovered by the historian Armand Nicolas describes the events thusly: “It is an armed insurrection, prepared for a long time... by almost the entire colored population of a district of the colony, with whom conspirators from another district and even from several others had colluded to carry out the pillage, devastation and burning of the colony, to massacre all the whites there in order to seize their property.” The members of the Assize Court of Saint-Pierre, presided over by de Perinelle and composed of advisors Richard de Lucy, Le Pelletier, and Duclary, the same ones who condemned Bissette and his comrades, were all white Creoles. They sentenced 141 individuals of color to various punishments.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">
                </tei-p>
                <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl">Nicolas, Armand,  <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Histoire de la Martinique, Des Arawaks à 1848</tei-emph> , Paris, L’Harmattan, 1996</tei-bibl>
                <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl">"Arsène Nogues,"  <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Man8rove.</tei-emph>  https://man8rove.com/fr/profile/a1r52vc3-arsene-nogues</tei-bibl>
                <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl">"CHAUVITEAU Jean Joseph Albert (1775-1823),"  <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Cimetière du Père-Lachaise</tei-emph> , 3 septembre 2023, https://www.appl-lachaise.net/chauviteau-jean-joseph-albert-1775-1823/</tei-bibl>
            </tei-note>
            <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="Person" resp="#abel" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type xml:lang">
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Né à Redon le 12 juin 1798, il occupe divers postes à Brest et à Nancy et est aussi procureur général en Guadeloupe puis en Martinique durant les années 1830. Puis, il est ensuite conseiller à la cour royale de Rouen en 1845. Marié à la fille d’un négociant et planteur de café d’origine guadeloupéenne, Jean Joseph Albert Chaviteau, qui se fixa à Cuba au début du XIXe siècle, il est donc lié fortement au milieu des colons. Arsène Nogues, est celui qui représente le ministère public en tant que procureur général lors de l’affaire de la Grande Anse (commune du Lorrain aujourd’hui) en décembre 1833. L’historien Armand Nicolas cite ainsi l’acte d’accusation en juin 1834 que Arsène Nogues dresse en notifiant que : “C’est une insurrection à main armée, préparée depuis longtemps... par la presque totalité de la population de couleur d’un quartier de la colonie, avec laquelle des conspirateurs d’un autre quartier et même de plusieurs autres s’étaient entendus pour porter le pillage, la dévastation et l’incendie de la colonie, pour y massacrer tous les Blancs afin de s’emparer de leurs biens”. Au nombre des membres de la Cour d’Assises de Saint-Pierre présidée par de Perinelle et composée de conseillers (Richard de Lucy, Le Pelletier Duclary), tous blancs créoles, les mêmes qui ont condamné Bissette et ses camarades, se trouve donc des hommes imbus de leurs pouvoirs discrétionnaires. Ils vont condamner 141 individus de couleur à diverses peines.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">
                </tei-p>
                <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl">Nicolas, Armand,  <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Histoire de la Martinique, Des Arawaks à 1848</tei-emph> , Paris, L’Harmattan, 1996</tei-bibl>
                <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl">"Arsène Nogues,"  <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Man8rove.</tei-emph>  https://man8rove.com/fr/profile/a1r52vc3-arsene-nogues</tei-bibl>
                <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl">"CHAUVITEAU Jean Joseph Albert (1775-1823),"  <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Cimetière du Père-Lachaise</tei-emph> , 3 septembre 2023, https://www.appl-lachaise.net/chauviteau-jean-joseph-albert-1775-1823/</tei-bibl>
            </tei-note>
